1.description: During the first two weeks of pregnancy, you are technically not pregnant yet. During these weeks, you will menstruate, after which your body will prepare to ovulate. You’re not technically pregnant yet, since doctors calculate your due date from the first day of your last period.
body_changes: You’ll experience your typical menstruation symptoms: bleeding, cramping, sore breasts, mood swings, etc.
1.baby_development: Technically the baby has not started developing yet.
tips: Adequate exercise
A balanced diet
Prenatal vitamins
Folic Acid
planning: Eat balanced diet
Start exercising

2.description: During week two of pregnancy, you are still not pregnant yet. During these weeks, you will menstruate, after which your body will prepare to ovulate. Ovulation occurs during week two. Your ovary will release a mature egg that travels into the Fallopian tube, where it awaits fertilization with sperm.
body_changes: Symptoms of ovulation include:
Twinging lower abdominal pain (Mittelschmerz - one-sided, lower abdominal pain associated with ovulation)
Breast tenderness
Slippery discharge that resembles egg white
Increased basal body temperature
Some women may experience light spotting during ovulation.
2.baby_development: Technically the baby has not started developing yet.
tips: The most important thing you can do right now is to act in the way you would if you already knew you were pregnant.
planning: Eat balanced diet
Start exercising

3.description: The third week is around the time that ovulation and conception occur. During this week, fetal development will begin, known as Gestational Age.
body_changes: Many women do not notice any changes, but some may experience mild cramping and increased vaginal discharge.
Some women may experience mild abdominal cramping or light spotting known as 'implantation bleeding.'
3.baby_development: The embryo is very small, the size of the head of a pin, approximately 0.48 mm long. Significant development begins, including the brain and heart.
tips: Get adequate rest and nutrition.
Use techniques to keep stress levels low.
planning: Exercise is important; consult your healthcare provider before starting.
Focus on nutrition, including folic acid and essential nutrients.

4.description: Between the fourth and seventh weeks is when many women discover they are pregnant. Symptoms may begin to appear.
body_changes: Early pregnancy symptoms may include breast tenderness, headaches, lower backaches, and nausea.
4.baby_development: Babies measure about 1.98 mm in length. The three layers of the baby begin to form organs and tissues, and the placenta starts producing hormones.
tips: Check with your healthcare provider about exercise.
Ensure your prenatal vitamin contains adequate folic acid.
planning: Consider taking a home pregnancy test if your period is late.
Look for a healthcare provider for your pregnancy.

5.description: During the fifth week, you may want to schedule your first prenatal appointment. Morning sickness may begin.
body_changes: Hormone-induced mood swings and fatigue may occur.
Other symptoms may include breast tenderness and nausea.
5.baby_development: Your baby measures 3 mm long. The heart is beating, and structures for the eyes and ears are forming.
tips: Expect a weight gain of 11.3 to 15.9 kg during pregnancy.
Consult your doctor about weight management.
planning: Schedule your first prenatal visit.
Narrow down your choice of healthcare provider.

6.description: In week six, you may experience nausea, breast changes, and heartburn. Vital organs are developing.
body_changes: Weight gain or loss may occur.
Breast tenderness and heartburn are common.
6.baby_development: Your baby is about 19.05 mm long. Development of the lungs, jaw, and palate has begun, with an audible heartbeat detectable via ultrasound.
tips: Take prenatal vitamins with food or at night to avoid nausea.
Consult your provider if you cannot tolerate them.
planning: Know your blood type and your partner’s blood type.
Understand Rh factor implications for pregnancy.

7.description: By the seventh week, every vital organ has begun to develop in your baby’s body. Morning sickness and frequent urination are common symptoms.
body_changes: You may have gained a couple of pounds, but losing weight due to morning sickness is not uncommon.
Gradual body changes occur, but it may not be noticeable to others.
7.baby_development: Your baby is approximately 2.54 cm long and weighs less than an aspirin. Every essential organ has begun to form.
tips: Eat small meals often.
Get plenty of rest and consider ginger or lemon for nausea.
Avoid spicy foods and consider taking Vitamin B6.
planning: Choose a healthcare provider if you haven't already.
Monitor severe morning sickness symptoms and consult your doctor.

8.description: During the eighth week, you may experience morning sickness, and your baby is growing. Your first prenatal appointment may occur this month.
body_changes: You may notice changes in your breasts as they prepare for lactation.
Your uterus has grown significantly.
8.baby_development: The embryo is a little over 2.54 cm long, with all major structures present. Facial features continue to develop.
tips: Consult your healthcare provider about acne treatments.
Discuss your medical history during your first prenatal visit.
planning: Expect a longer first prenatal appointment to discuss medical history and undergo exams.

9.description: At nine weeks, your baby is about the size of a grape. Digestive changes may lead to constipation and gas.
body_changes: You may experience mood swings, heartburn, and bloating.
Prevent heartburn by eating smaller meals.
9.baby_development: Your baby is around 4.24 cm long, with fully formed eyelids and joints that allow movement.
tips: Consider changing sleeping positions if you experience fatigue.
Stay hydrated and manage heartburn.
planning: Discuss genetic counseling if you have a family history of genetic illnesses.

10.description: By the 10th week, most of your baby’s organs are present and will continue to mature. You may notice physical changes.
body_changes: Your uterus has continued to grow, but you may not be showing much yet.
Discuss your feelings and adjustments to pregnancy with your partner.
10.baby_development: Your baby is over 5 cm long and weighs about 7 grams. This marks the end of the embryonic period.
tips: Stay active with low-impact exercises like walking and swimming.
Consult with your healthcare provider about suitable activities.
planning: Prepare for your second prenatal visit between weeks 12 and 16, where an ultrasound may occur.

11.description: At 11 weeks, you are nearing the end of the first trimester. Your baby is becoming more active, and you may experience round ligament pain.
body_changes: Changes in hair and nail growth are common due to hormonal changes.
You may notice clear discharge (leukorrhea) as your body clears bacteria.
11.baby_development: Your baby is over 6.35 cm long and weighs about 14.17 grams. The external genitalia is almost fully formed, and fingers and toes are separated.
tips: Travel is generally safe during pregnancy, especially in the second trimester.
Manage morning sickness and monitor your weight gain.
planning: Aim for a weight gain of 3 to 4 pounds during the first trimester.

12.description: You are almost finished with the first trimester. Your baby is growing, and blood volume increases significantly.
body_changes: Your uterus is growing, and your healthcare provider can feel it in your abdomen.
You may notice changes in your skin, including darkening areolas and chloasma.
12.baby_development: Your baby is 8 cm long and weighs about 28 grams. The baby’s eyes and ears are moving closer to their final positions.
tips: Consider Kegel exercises to strengthen pelvic muscles.
Focus on a balanced diet to support your baby’s growth.
planning: Ensure steady weight gain and avoid excessive junk food.

13.description: As you finish the first trimester, early pregnancy symptoms may diminish, but you might feel dizzy due to anemia.
body_changes: You may notice stretch marks and changes in breast size and appearance.
Morning sickness may subside, but heartburn might become more frequent.
13.baby_development: Your baby is about 9.5 cm long and weighs 35 grams. Unique fingerprints have developed, and the skin is covered with lanugo.
tips: Maintain a healthy weight to reduce the appearance of stretch marks.
Continue taking Folic Acid and Ferrous Sulphate.
planning: It's generally safe to have sexual intercourse unless there are complications.

14.description: Congratulations on entering the second trimester! You may experience increased appetite and energy.
body_changes: Maternity clothes might be necessary as your body adjusts.
Your body responds differently with subsequent pregnancies.
14.baby_development: Your baby is over 10 cm long and weighs just under 57 grams. Arm length is increasing, and the liver starts producing bile.
tips: Monitor any changes in moles and consult a healthcare provider if necessary.
Stay active and manage stress effectively.
planning: Prepare for emotional changes and seek ways to cope with stress.

15.description: By the 15th week, your doctor may start measuring your fundal height to monitor growth.
body_changes: You may experience stuffy nose, leg cramps, and increased clumsiness.
Average weight gain is about 5 pounds, but variations are normal.
15.baby_development: Your baby is 12 cm long and weighs 57 grams. The bones are beginning to ossify, and visible movement may be detected on ultrasound.
tips: Sleep on your side to ensure proper circulation.
Use pillows for support to maintain a comfortable position.
planning: Your healthcare provider will monitor fundal height at appointments.

16.description: Entering week 16, your blood volume has increased. You may notice a 'pregnancy glow.'
body_changes: Your uterus weighs around 0.25 kg, and you may notice darkened skin in various areas.
Increased blood circulation can lead to a brighter complexion.
16.baby_development: Your baby is approximately 13.5 cm long and weighs about 70 grams. The heart pumps 23.7 liters of blood daily.
tips: Expect to feel your baby’s first movements between weeks 16 and 22.
Continue sleeping on your side for comfort and health.
planning: Discuss any upcoming tests or screenings with your healthcare provider.

17.description: By the 17th week, you are well into your second trimester. Your baby is developing adipose, and you may experience sciatic nerve pain.
body_changes: You may feel backaches and experience forgetfulness, often referred to as 'pregnancy brain.'
Your abdomen is growing, and other organs are adjusting to make room.
17.baby_development: Your baby is about 14.5 cm long and weighs 113 grams. The umbilical cord is strengthening, and the baby's sense of hearing is developing.
tips: If experiencing sciatic nerve pain, consult your healthcare provider.
Discuss allergy medications with your doctor.
planning: Monitor any allergy symptoms and consult with your healthcare provider.

18.description: At 18 weeks, your pregnancy bump is more noticeable, and you may need to rest more during the day.
body_changes: You may experience weight gain and stretch marks as your belly expands.
Your cardiovascular system is affected, leading to low blood pressure.
18.baby_development: Your baby is about 16 cm long and weighs 156 grams. Myelin is forming around the nerves, and if you have a girl, her reproductive organs are positioning correctly.
tips: Take advantage of nap opportunities during the day.
Prepare for your third prenatal appointment.
planning: Expect procedures like a sonogram or Maternal Serum Alpha-Fetoprotein Screening.

19.description: During the 19th week, you may experience round ligament pain and dizziness.
body_changes: Heartburn may occur due to hormonal changes.
Constipation might also be an issue.
19.baby_development: Your baby is about 17.8 cm long and weighs 200 grams. The kidneys are producing urine, and hair is starting to grow on the scalp.
tips: Sleep on your side to alleviate dizziness.
Consult your healthcare provider before using herbal remedies.
planning: Be cautious with herbal remedies; consult your healthcare provider.

20.description: Congratulations on reaching the halfway point of your pregnancy! Your baby might be kicking more.
body_changes: You may have gained around 8 to 10 pounds by now.
Expect to gain about 0.23 to 0.45 kg per week going forward.
20.baby_development: Your baby is about 19.7 cm long and weighs 260 grams. Vernix caseosa is forming to protect the skin.
tips: Ensure you are getting enough iron in your diet.
Consider keeping a journal for your birth plan.
planning: Start creating a birth plan to communicate your wishes for delivery.

21.description: At 21 weeks, you are enjoying your second trimester, but round ligament pain may increase.
body_changes: You might experience shortness of breath due to pressure from the growing uterus.
Swelling in legs and feet may occur.
21.baby_development: Your baby is over 21.6 cm long and weighs 340 grams. The digestive tract is maturing, and movements may be felt consistently.
tips: Stay hydrated to prevent urinary tract infections (UTIs).
Monitor any swelling or discomfort.
planning: Discuss plans for maternity leave with your employer.

22.description: By 22 weeks, your baby resembles a newborn but will continue to develop.
body_changes: The top of your uterus is about 5 cm above your belly button.
You may experience skin changes, including stretch marks.
22.baby_development: Your baby is 25 cm long and weighs 400 grams. The pancreas is maturing, and the skin appears wrinkly due to lack of fat.
tips: Be aware of signs of preterm labor.
Consider signing up for childbirth education classes.
planning: Arrange for childbirth education classes to prepare for labor.

23.description: At 23 weeks, your baby is developing further, and it's a good time to finalize maternity leave plans.
body_changes: Your uterus is now about 3.8 cm above your belly button.
You may notice leaks due to pressure on your bladder.
23.baby_development: Your baby weighs about 450 grams and is approximately 28 to 36 cm long. Lanugo is developing, and the baby is looking more like a newborn.
tips: Stay hydrated to help prevent leg cramps and other discomforts.
Monitor any fluid leaking and consult your provider.
planning: Discuss your plans for maternity leave with HR and your supervisor.

24.description: By the 24th week, your baby's brain and lungs are maturing rapidly.
body_changes: You might experience itchy skin as your abdomen stretches.
Dry eyes and skin sensitivity may also occur.
24.baby_development: Your baby is over 32 cm long and weighs between 600 to 700 grams. Surfactant production in the lungs is beginning.
tips: Eat smaller meals to manage heartburn effectively.
Use moisturizers to relieve itchy skin.
planning: Prepare for a glucose screening test between 24 and 28 weeks.

25.description: At 25 weeks, your uterus is about the size of a soccer ball, and you may be able to determine your baby's gender.
body_changes: You might experience tingling in your hands due to carpal tunnel syndrome.
Your uterus can be felt halfway between your belly button and sternum.
25.baby_development: Your baby is about 33 cm long and weighs between 0.7 to 0.8 kg. Fat is accumulating, and hair color and texture may be visible.
tips: Start thinking about baby names.
Discuss any interest in amniocentesis or CVS with your doctor.
planning: Consider the implications of keepsake ultrasounds and consult with your healthcare provider.

26.description: At 26 weeks, you're nearing the third trimester and can expect routine screenings at your next appointment.
body_changes: The top of your uterus is now about 6.3 cm above your belly button.
You may experience sleep disturbances due to leg cramps and frequent urination.
26.baby_development: Your baby is approximately 34 cm long and weighs about 0.9 kg. Ears are developing, and your baby is swallowing amniotic fluid.
tips: Incorporate nutritious meals like okra soup into your diet.
Monitor your weight gain.
planning: Prepare for blood screenings and glucose tolerance tests.

27.description: You have begun your third trimester! This is a good time to pick out an infant car seat.
body_changes: You may feel more baby movements, including hiccups.
Some women may experience hemorrhoids due to increased blood flow.
27.baby_development: Your baby is about 35 cm long and weighs around 1 kg. Eyelids can open and close, and a sleep cycle is developing.
tips: Choose an infant car seat and ensure it fits properly in your vehicle.
Discuss childbirth classes with your partner.
planning: Enroll in childbirth classes to prepare for labor.

28.description: By the 28th week, you will have more frequent antenatal appointments and may feel physically exhausted.
body_changes: The top of your uterus can be felt about 8.9 cm above your belly button.
You may experience shortness of breath due to pressure on your diaphragm.
28.baby_development: Your baby is approximately 36 cm long and weighs about 1.13 kg. The brain is developing grooves, and hair growth continues.
tips: Plan your trip to the hospital in advance.
Keep emergency contact numbers handy.
planning: Prepare for regular prenatal visits every two weeks.

29.description: At 29 weeks, focus on getting adequate nutrients and rest.
body_changes: Colostrum may leak from your breasts as your body prepares for breastfeeding.
You may notice increased discomfort from constipation.
29.baby_development: Your baby is now 37 cm long and weighs about 1.25 kg. Rapid growth continues, and brain development is significant.
tips: Stay hydrated to prevent constipation.
Discuss your birth plan with your partner.
planning: Consider hiring a community healthcare worker for support during delivery.

30.description: You may feel more tired, and your joints might feel looser as you approach the final weeks.
body_changes: You may experience aches and heartburn.
Your feet may increase in size due to hormonal changes.
30.baby_development: Your baby is about 38.5 cm long and weighs around 1.4 kg. Eyes are maturing, and they can distinguish between light and dark.
tips: Evaluate your posture to relieve back pain.
Experiment with different sleeping positions for comfort.
planning: Research pain relief options for delivery.

31.description: At 31 weeks, you may begin experiencing Braxton Hicks contractions and leaking colostrum.
body_changes: You might feel more tired, and your breasts may become tender.
Frequent urination may occur due to pressure from the baby's head.
31.baby_development: Your baby is 39.4 cm long and weighs between 1.6 to 1.8 kg. The baby is developing a layer of fat and is becoming more rounded.
tips: Use nursing pads to manage colostrum leakage.
Practice relaxation techniques for Braxton Hicks contractions.
planning: Decide on breastfeeding or bottle feeding options.

32.description: By 32 weeks, you will have appointments every two weeks and should start planning for cord blood storage.
body_changes: You may experience shortness of breath due to pressure on your diaphragm.
You might have increased heartburn as your uterus grows.
32.baby_development: Your baby is about 40.6 cm long and weighs between 1.8 to 2 kg. The brain is developing grooves, and the lungs are maturing.
tips: Alleviate Braxton Hicks contractions by changing positions.
Stay hydrated to manage discomfort.
planning: Discuss cord blood storage options with your healthcare provider.

33.description: At 33 weeks, you may want to discuss episiotomy options with your doctor.
body_changes: The top of your uterus is about 12.7 cm from your belly button.
You may have increased discomfort and swelling.
33.baby_development: Your baby is approximately 42 cm long and weighs between 2 to 2.3 kg. The skin is becoming less wrinkled as fat develops.
tips: Explore comfortable positions for sexual intercourse.
Monitor for signs of premature labor.
planning: Discuss the necessity of an episiotomy with your healthcare provider.

34.description: By the 34th week, your baby’s lungs are well-developed. You might experience various pregnancy symptoms as you prepare for labor.
body_changes: The top of your uterus can be felt about 14 cm above your belly button.
You may notice increased Braxton Hicks contractions as you approach labor.
34.baby_development: Your baby is around 44.5 cm long and weighs between 2.3 to 2.5 kg. Fat is accumulating, helping with temperature regulation after birth.
tips: Consider massaging your perineum to prevent an episiotomy.
Discuss labor stages with your healthcare provider.
planning: Prepare for tests like the Group B Strep test and discuss pain management options.

35.description: At 35 weeks, you may feel short of breath and notice changes in your baby's movements.
body_changes: The top of your uterus is about 15.2 cm above your belly button.
You might experience increased Braxton Hicks contractions.
35.baby_development: Your baby is between 43.2 to 45.7 cm long and weighs around 2.5 to 2.7 kg. The kidneys are fully developed, and the liver begins processing waste.
tips: Start tracking your baby’s kick counts for reassurance.
Find a pediatrician and discuss their policies.
planning: Prepare for weekly visits as you approach your due date.

36.description: At 36 weeks, you may experience increased Braxton Hicks contractions and should pack your hospital bag.
body_changes: The top of your uterus is about 15.2 cm above your belly button.
You may notice more pelvic pressure as your baby drops.
36.baby_development: Your baby is likely between 44.5 to 48.3 cm long and weighs around 2.6 to 3.1 kg. Lanugo and vernix are disappearing as fat accumulates.
tips: Consider using a nursing bra for comfort.
Discuss any final preparations with your healthcare provider.
planning: Ensure your hospital bag is packed with essentials.

37.description: During week 37, your cervix may begin to dilate and efface as labor approaches.
body_changes: You might experience pelvic discomfort and some spotting.
Braxton Hicks contractions may increase in frequency.
37.baby_development: Your baby is approximately 45.7 to 50.8 cm long and weighs around 2.7 to 3.2 kg. Most organs are fully functional, with ongoing development.
tips: Finish any last-minute preparations for your baby.
Monitor for signs of labor, including changes in movement.
planning: Discuss labor and delivery options with your healthcare provider.

38.description: At 38 weeks, most baby organs are functional, and you could go into labor at any time.
body_changes: You may experience swelling, especially in the feet.
Watch for signs of pregnancy-induced hypertension.
38.baby_development: Your baby is between 43.2 to 50.8 cm long and weighs around 2.8 to 3.4 kg. Most organs are mature, with ongoing brain and lung development.
tips: Consider scheduling a sonogram if your baby is breech.
Enjoy this time as you prepare for birth.
planning: Discuss any remaining questions with your healthcare provider.

39.description: At 39 weeks, labor could start at any moment. Monitor for early signs, such as contractions and water breaking.
body_changes: You likely won't notice significant changes but may feel discomfort.
Cervical effacement is progressing.
39.baby_development: Your baby is between 45.7 to 52 cm long and weighs about 2.9 to 3.6 kg. Fat continues to accumulate for temperature regulation.
tips: Continue counting baby movements.
Keep tags on baby gifts until you confirm sizes.
planning: Prepare for potential hospital visits and labor.

40.description: Congratulations on reaching the end of your pregnancy! You may meet your baby this week.
body_changes: You may experience various symptoms until labor begins.
Monitor for signs of complications like postpartum hemorrhage.
40.baby_development: Your baby is about 48.3 to 53.3 cm long and weighs between 3 to 4.5 kg. The skull remains soft for delivery.
tips: Be aware of the APGAR test post-birth.
Practice breathing techniques to manage labor.
planning: Discuss final tests and preparations with your healthcare provider.
